p: We proposed a new model of aggression and violence, called CLimate, Aggression, and Self-control in Humans (CLASH; van Lange et al., 2017b), to understand differences in aggression and violence within and between countries in terms of differences in climate (see Figure 2). To explicate the logic and to facilitate empirical tests, we have advanced two broad propositions of CLASH (for an extensive discussion, partly summarized here, see van Lange et al., 2017b). The first proposition is that lower temperatures and especially greater seasonal variation in temperature influence individuals and societies to adopt a greater future orientation and enhanced self-control (Proposition 1). The second proposition is that self-control and future time orientation are important inhibitors of aggression and violence (Proposition 2).
